$\mathrm{Pic}(\overline{M}_{g,n})\to \mathrm{Pic}(\Mgn)$ is torsion (equivalently, line bundles descend
after some tensor power).
\end{remark}

\begin{lemma}[Nefness descends to the coarse space]\label{lem:nef-descends}
If $L_i$ is nef on $\Mgn$, then $M_i$ is nef on $\overline{M}_{g,n}$, hence
$\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}$ is nef as a $\Q$-Cartier divisor class.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}[Proof sketch]
Let $C\subset \overline{M}_{g,n}$ be an irreducible curve and $\widetilde C\to C$ its normalization.
Consider the base change $\Mgn\times_{\overline{M}_{g,n}}\widetilde C$ and choose an irreducible
component $\widetilde{\mathcal C}$ dominating $\widetilde C$; then
$\widetilde{\mathcal C}\to \widetilde C$ is finite surjective.
Pulling back $p^*M_i\simeq L_i^{\otimes m_i}$ to $\widetilde{\mathcal C}$ gives
\[
\deg(M_i|_{\widetilde C})\cdot \deg(\widetilde{\mathcal C}\to \widetilde C)
=
\deg(L_i^{\otimes m_i}|_{\widetilde{\mathcal C}})\ge 0,
\]
since $L_i$ is nef on the stack.
Thus $\deg(M_i|_{\widetilde C})\ge 0$ for all curves, i.e.\ $M_i$ is nef.
\end{proof}

Now choose a resolution of singularities $\pi:\widetilde X\to \overline{M}_{g,n}$ with $\widetilde X$
smooth projective of dimension $d$. Set $\widetilde\psic_i:=\pi^*\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}$; this is
nef on $\widetilde X$.

\begin{lemma}[Computing top intersections on a resolution]\label{lem:resolution}
Let $\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_d\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^1(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$ be $\Q$-Cartier divisor
classes. Then
\[
\degop\bigl((\alpha_1\cdots\alpha_d)\cap[\overline{M}_{g,n}]\bigr)
=
\degop\bigl((\pi^*\alpha_1\cdots\pi^*\alpha_d)\cap[\widetilde X]\bigr).
\]
In particular, for $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$,
\[
D(\mathbf e)
=
\int_{\widetilde X}\widetilde\psic_1^{e_1}\cdots \widetilde\psic_n^{e_n}.
\tag{$\ast$}\label{eq:Dtilde}
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Write $\alpha:=\alpha_1\cdots\alpha_d\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^d(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$.
By definition of cap product and the projection formula in operational Chow,
\[
\alpha\cap[\overline{M}_{g,n}]
=
\alpha\cap \pi_*[\widetilde X]
=
\pi_*(\pi^*\alpha\cap[\widetilde X]).
\]
Taking degrees gives the claim.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}
Schmitt instead reduces to schemes by choosing a finite flat cover of $\Mgn$ by a complete scheme and
applying Khovanskii--Teissier there \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Both routes are standard; \eqref{eq:Dtilde} is convenient for directly invoking the classical
smooth-projective form of Alexandrov--Fenchel.
\end{remark}

\section{Log-concavity of two-point slices via Alexandrov--Fenchel}\label{sec:logconcave}

Fix $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ and distinct indices $i\neq j$. Let $q:=e_i+e_j$ and let
\[
C := \prod_{k\neq i,j}\widetilde\psic_k^{e_k}.
\]
For $t=0,1,\dots,q$ define the slice values
\[
S_t := \int_{\widetilde X}\widetilde\psic_i^{t}\,\widetilde\psic_j^{q-t}\,C.
\]
Thus $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$ (by \eqref{eq:Dtilde}).

\begin{lemma}[Palindromicity]\label{lem:pal}
$S_t=S_{q-t}$ for all $t$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
This is induced by the automorphism of $\Mgn$ swapping the $i$-th and $j$-th markings, which exchanges
$\psic_i$ and $\psic_j$ while fixing all other $\psic_k$. (Formally, one checks this on the stack and
then uses \eqref{eq:Dtilde}.)
\end{proof}

\subsection{Alexandrov--Fenchel / Khovanskii--Teissier}

We use the following standard inequality for nef divisor classes; see \cite[\S1.6]{Laz04}.

\begin{theorem}[Khovanskii--Teissier (2-by-2 form)]\label{thm:AF}
Let $Y$ be a smooth projective variety of dimension $d$ and let $D_1,\dots,D_d$ be nef
$\R$-Cartier divisor classes on $Y$. Then
\[
(D_1\cdots D_d)^2 \;\ge\; (D_1^2D_3\cdots D_d)\,(D_2^2D_3\cdots D_d).
\tag{AF}\label{eq:AF}
\]
\end{theorem}

\begin{lemma}[Slice log-concavity]\label{lem:lc}
For $1\le t\le q-1$ one has
\[
S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}.
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Apply Theorem~\ref{thm:AF} on $Y=\widetilde X$ with the following list of nef divisors:
\[
D_1=\widetilde\psic_i,\qquad D_2=\widetilde\psic_j,
\]
and $D_3,\dots,D_d$ consisting of
\begin{itemize}[leftmargin=2em]
\item $t-1$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_i$,
\item $q-t-1$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_j$,
\item and for each $k\neq i,j$, $e_k$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_k$.
\end{itemize}
The divisor count is $2+(t-1)+(q-t-1)+\sum_{k\neq i,j}e_k = q+\sum_{k\neq i,j}e_k = d$.
With this choice,
\[
(D_1\cdots D_d)=S_t,\quad (D_1^2D_3\cdots D_d)=S_{t+1},\quad (D_2^2D_3\cdots D_d)=S_{t-1},
\]
so \eqref{eq:AF} becomes $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$.
\end{proof}

\section{A discrete unimodality lemma without strict positivity}\label{sec:unimod}

Let $(S_t)_{t=0}^q$ be a nonnegative real sequence.

\begin{lemma}[Contiguous support]\label{lem:support}
If $S_t\ge 0$ and $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$ for all $1\le t\le q-1$, then
$\{t:\; S_t>0\}$ is an interval (possibly empty).
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
If $S_m=0$ and $S_{m-1}>0$, then $0=S_m^2\ge S_{m-1}S_{m+1}$ forces $S_{m+1}=0$.
Iterating forward and backward shows there are no internal zeros.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Palindromic log-concave sequences peak at the center]\label{lem:center}
Assume $(S_t)$ is nonnegative, log-concave (as above), and palindromic $S_t=S_{q-t}$.
Let $m=\lfloor q/2\rfloor$. Then for every integer $t\ge m+1$ one has
\[
S_{t-1}\ge S_t.
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
By Lemma~\ref{lem:support}, positivity holds on a contiguous interval, and the inequality is trivial
outside that interval. We therefore assume $S_t>0$ on the relevant range.

Define ratios $R_t:=S_{t}/S_{t-1}$ (for $1\le t\le q$). Log-concavity implies $R_{t+1}\le R_t$:
indeed $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$ is equivalent to $S_t/S_{t-1}\ge S_{t+1}/S_t$.

If $q=2m$ is even, palindromicity gives $S_{m-1}=S_{m+1}$, hence log-concavity at $m$ implies
\[
S_m^2\ge S_{m-1}S_{m+1}=S_{m+1}^2,
\]
so $S_m\ge S_{m+1}$, i.e.\ $R_{m+1}\le 1$. Since $(R_t)$ is weakly decreasing, for all $t\ge m+1$ we
have $R_t\le R_{m+1}\le 1$, i.e.\ $S_t\le S_{t-1}$.

If $q=2m+1$ is odd, palindromicity gives $S_m=S_{m+1}$, so $R_{m+1}=1$. Again monotonicity gives
$R_t\le 1$ for all $t\ge m+1$, hence $S_t\le S_{t-1}$.
\end{proof}

\section{Proof of the transfer inequality and Theorem~\ref{thm:main}}\label{sec:proof}

We now return to the descendant function $D$.

\begin{proposition}[Transfer inequality for $D$]\label{prop:TI-for-D}
Let $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ and suppose $e_i\ge e_j+2$. Then
\[
D(\mathbf e)\le D(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j).
\]
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Fix $\mathbf e$ and $i\neq j$ and form the slice sequence $S_t$ as in
Section~\ref{sec:logconcave}, with $q=e_i+e_j$ and $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$.
Lemma~\ref{lem:lc} gives log-concavity, and Lemma~\ref{lem:pal} gives palindromicity.
Since $e_i\ge e_j+2$, we have $e_i>\frac{q}{2}$, i.e.\ $e_i\ge \lfloor q/2\rfloor+1$.
Applying Lemma~\ref{lem:center} yields
\[
S_{e_i-1}\ge S_{e_i}.
\]
But $S_{e_i-1}=D(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j)$ and $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$, giving the claim.
\end{proof}

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{thm:main}]
By Proposition~\ref{prop:TI-for-D}, the descendant function $D$ satisfies the transfer inequality
\eqref{eq:TI}. Theorem~\ref{thm:main} now follows from Proposition~\ref{prop:reduce}.
\end{proof}

\section{Comments on \cite{Schmitt2025}}\label{sec:comparison}

This section is optional and can be shortened substantially.

\subsection{Comparison of reductions to the Khovanskii--Teissier setting}

Schmitt's main theorem asserts a maximum at balanced vectors and a minimum at concentrated vectors
\cite[Thm.\ 1.2]{Schmitt2025}. The maximality proof in \cite[\S2.1]{Schmitt2025} is presented as
model-generated and invokes Khovanskii--Teissier log-concavity for nef classes on a projective
orbifold, together with the remark that one may pass from the stack to a smooth projective variety by
a finite level-structure cover \cite[Rem.\ 2.1]{Schmitt2025}.

In \cite[\S3]{Schmitt2025}, Schmitt instead reduces to a finite flat cover by a complete scheme and
applies Lazarsfeld's inequality there using the projection formula \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Our Section~\ref{sec:stack-bridge} provides a third standard bridge: pass to the coarse moduli space,
use operational Chow, then compute intersections on a resolution. No new mathematics is involved; the
goal is simply to make every reduction step explicit.

\subsection{Positivity vs.\ nonnegativity in the unimodality step}

Schmitt's optimization theorem formalized in Lean assumes strict positivity (P)
\cite[Thm.\ 3.1]{Schmitt2025} to justify ratio arguments in slice sequences. For descendant integrals,
positivity is known (e.g.\ from Witten--Kontsevich recursions, as Schmitt notes) \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Nevertheless, Lemmas~\ref{lem:support}--\ref{lem:center} show that the ``move toward the center does
not decrease'' conclusion only needs nonnegativity plus log-concavity and palindromicity.

\cite[Thm.\ 1.2]{Schmitt2025}. Our focus here is the maximization statement.

\begin{theorem}[Balanced vectors maximize $D$]\label{thm:main}
Assume $n\ge 1$ and $2g-2+n>0$. Then the function $D:E(g,n)\to \Q$ attains its maximum at a balanced
vector.
\end{theorem}

\begin{remark}[Relation with \cite{Schmitt2025}]
Schmitt's proof of maximality (his \S2.1) is short and conceptual, relying on nefness of the
$\psic_i$ and Khovanskii--Teissier log-concavity \cite[\S2.1]{Schmitt2025}.
Section~\ref{sec:comparison} below records the precise points where our write-up differs:
we spell out one possible stack-to-variety reduction, and we isolate a discrete lemma that avoids
assuming strict positivity of the slice sequence (though Schmitt also provides positivity via
recursions in \cite[\S3]{Schmitt2025}).
\end{remark}

\section{A discrete reduction via balancing moves}\label{sec:balancing}

Throughout this section, fix integers $n\ge 1$ and $d\ge 0$ and write
\[
E(n,d):=\{\mathbf e\in \Z_{\ge 0}^n:\; \sum_i e_i=d\}.
\]
For $1\le i\le n$, let $\delta_i\in \Z^n$ be the $i$-th standard basis vector.

\begin{definition}[Balancing move]
If $\mathbf e\in E(n,d)$ and $e_i\ge e_j+2$, the \emph{balancing move} (or \emph{Robin Hood transfer})
from $i$ to $j$ is
\[
\mathbf e\longmapsto \mathbf e - \delta_i + \delta_j.
\]
\end{definition}

\begin{lemma}[Termination of balancing moves]\label{lem:terminate}
Starting from any $\mathbf e\in E(n,d)$, iterating balancing moves terminates after finitely many
steps at a balanced vector.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Let $\bar e:=d/n$ and consider the integer-valued potential
\[
\Phi(\mathbf e):=\sum_{k=1}^n (e_k-\bar e)^2.
\]
If $e_i\ge e_j+2$ and $\mathbf e'=\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j$, then a direct computation shows
\[
\Phi(\mathbf e')-\Phi(\mathbf e)=2(e_j-e_i)+2\le -2.
\]
Thus $\Phi$ strictly decreases along balancing moves and is bounded below by $0$, so the process
terminates. Termination means no pair satisfies $e_i\ge e_j+2$, i.e.\ the terminal vector is balanced.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}[Reduction to a pairwise transfer inequality]\label{prop:reduce}
Let $F:E(n,d)\to \R$ be any function such that for all $\mathbf e\in E(n,d)$ and all $i\neq j$ with
$e_i\ge e_j+2$ one has
\[
F(\mathbf e)\le F(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j).
\tag{TI}\label{eq:TI}
\]
Then $F$ attains its maximum on $E(n,d)$ at a balanced vector.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Let $\mathbf e_{\max}$ be a maximizer. By Lemma~\ref{lem:terminate}, applying balancing moves to
$\mathbf e_{\max}$ produces a balanced vector $\mathbf b$. Along each move, $F$ weakly increases by
\eqref{eq:TI}, hence $F(\mathbf b)\ge F(\mathbf e_{\max})$, so $\mathbf b$ is a balanced maximizer.
\end{proof}

Thus, to prove Theorem~\ref{thm:main} for $D$ it suffices to establish \eqref{eq:TI} for $F=D$.

Each $\psic_i$ is nef on $\Mgn$.
\end{fact}

Schmitt cites nefness in \cite[\S2.1, Step 2]{Schmitt2025} and in \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}

Let $\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_d\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^1(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$ be $\Q$-Cartier divisor

\[
\degop\bigl((\alpha_1\cdots\alpha_d)\cap[\overline{M}_{g,n}]\bigr)
=
\degop\bigl((\pi^*\alpha_1\cdots\pi^*\alpha_d)\cap[\widetilde X]\bigr).

Write $\alpha:=\alpha_1\cdots\alpha_d\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^d(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$.
By definition of cap product and the projection formula in operational Chow,
\[
\alpha\cap[\overline{M}_{g,n}]
=
\alpha\cap \pi_*[\widetilde X]
=
\pi_*(\pi^*\alpha\cap[\widetilde X]).
\]
Taking degrees gives the claim.
\end{proof}

\end{remark}

\section{Log-concavity of two-point slices via Alexandrov--Fenchel}\label{sec:logconcave}

Fix $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ and distinct indices $i\neq j$. Let $q:=e_i+e_j$ and let
\[
C := \prod_{k\neq i,j}\widetilde\psic_k^{e_k}.
\]
For $t=0,1,\dots,q$ define the slice values
\[
S_t := \int_{\widetilde X}\widetilde\psic_i^{t}\,\widetilde\psic_j^{q-t}\,C.
\]
Thus $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$ (by \eqref{eq:Dtilde}).

\begin{lemma}[Palindromicity]\label{lem:pal}
$S_t=S_{q-t}$ for all $t$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
This is induced by the automorphism of $\Mgn$ swapping the $i$-th and $j$-th markings, which exchanges
$\psic_i$ and $\psic_j$ while fixing all other $\psic_k$. (Formally, one checks this on the stack and
then uses \eqref{eq:Dtilde}.)
\end{proof}

\subsection{Alexandrov--Fenchel / Khovanskii--Teissier}

We use the following standard inequality for nef divisor classes; see \cite[\S1.6]{Laz04}.

\begin{theorem}[Khovanskii--Teissier (2-by-2 form)]\label{thm:AF}
Let $Y$ be a smooth projective variety of dimension $d$ and let $D_1,\dots,D_d$ be nef
$\R$-Cartier divisor classes on $Y$. Then
\[
(D_1\cdots D_d)^2 \;\ge\; (D_1^2D_3\cdots D_d)\,(D_2^2D_3\cdots D_d).
\tag{AF}\label{eq:AF}
\]
\end{theorem}

\begin{lemma}[Slice log-concavity]\label{lem:lc}
For $1\le t\le q-1$ one has
\[
S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}.
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Apply Theorem~\ref{thm:AF} on $Y=\widetilde X$ with the following list of nef divisors:
\[
D_1=\widetilde\psic_i,\qquad D_2=\widetilde\psic_j,
\]
and $D_3,\dots,D_d$ consisting of
\begin{itemize}[leftmargin=2em]
\item $t-1$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_i$,
\item $q-t-1$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_j$,
\item and for each $k\neq i,j$, $e_k$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_k$.
\end{itemize}
The divisor count is $2+(t-1)+(q-t-1)+\sum_{k\neq i,j}e_k = q+\sum_{k\neq i,j}e_k = d$.
With this choice,
\[
(D_1\cdots D_d)=S_t,\quad (D_1^2D_3\cdots D_d)=S_{t+1},\quad (D_2^2D_3\cdots D_d)=S_{t-1},
\]
so \eqref{eq:AF} becomes $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$.
\end{proof}

\section{A discrete unimodality lemma without strict positivity}\label{sec:unimod}

Let $(S_t)_{t=0}^q$ be a nonnegative real sequence.

\begin{lemma}[Contiguous support]\label{lem:support}
If $S_t\ge 0$ and $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$ for all $1\le t\le q-1$, then
$\{t:\; S_t>0\}$ is an interval (possibly empty).
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
If $S_m=0$ and $S_{m-1}>0$, then $0=S_m^2\ge S_{m-1}S_{m+1}$ forces $S_{m+1}=0$.
Iterating forward and backward shows there are no internal zeros.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Palindromic log-concave sequences peak at the center]\label{lem:center}
Assume $(S_t)$ is nonnegative, log-concave (as above), and palindromic $S_t=S_{q-t}$.
Let $m=\lfloor q/2\rfloor$. Then for every integer $t\ge m+1$ one has
\[
S_{t-1}\ge S_t.
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
By Lemma~\ref{lem:support}, positivity holds on a contiguous interval, and the inequality is trivial
outside that interval. We therefore assume $S_t>0$ on the relevant range.

Define ratios $R_t:=S_{t}/S_{t-1}$ (for $1\le t\le q$). Log-concavity implies $R_{t+1}\le R_t$:
indeed $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$ is equivalent to $S_t/S_{t-1}\ge S_{t+1}/S_t$.

If $q=2m$ is even, palindromicity gives $S_{m-1}=S_{m+1}$, hence log-concavity at $m$ implies
\[
S_m^2\ge S_{m-1}S_{m+1}=S_{m+1}^2,
\]
so $S_m\ge S_{m+1}$, i.e.\ $R_{m+1}\le 1$. Since $(R_t)$ is weakly decreasing, for all $t\ge m+1$ we
have $R_t\le R_{m+1}\le 1$, i.e.\ $S_t\le S_{t-1}$.

If $q=2m+1$ is odd, palindromicity gives $S_m=S_{m+1}$, so $R_{m+1}=1$. Again monotonicity gives
$R_t\le 1$ for all $t\ge m+1$, hence $S_t\le S_{t-1}$.
\end{proof}

\section{Proof of the transfer inequality and Theorem~\ref{thm:main}}\label{sec:proof}

We now return to the descendant function $D$.

\begin{proposition}[Transfer inequality for $D$]\label{prop:TI-for-D}
Let $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ and suppose $e_i\ge e_j+2$. Then
\[
D(\mathbf e)\le D(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j).
\]
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Fix $\mathbf e$ and $i\neq j$ and form the slice sequence $S_t$ as in
Section~\ref{sec:logconcave}, with $q=e_i+e_j$ and $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$.
Lemma~\ref{lem:lc} gives log-concavity, and Lemma~\ref{lem:pal} gives palindromicity.
Since $e_i\ge e_j+2$, we have $e_i>\frac{q}{2}$, i.e.\ $e_i\ge \lfloor q/2\rfloor+1$.
Applying Lemma~\ref{lem:center} yields
\[
S_{e_i-1}\ge S_{e_i}.
\]
But $S_{e_i-1}=D(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j)$ and $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$, giving the claim.
\end{proof}

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{thm:main}]
By Proposition~\ref{prop:TI-for-D}, the descendant function $D$ satisfies the transfer inequality
\eqref{eq:TI}. Theorem~\ref{thm:main} now follows from Proposition~\ref{prop:reduce}.
\end{proof}

\section{Comments on \cite{Schmitt2025}}\label{sec:comparison}

This section is optional and can be shortened substantially.

\subsection{Comparison of reductions to the Khovanskii--Teissier setting}

Schmitt's main theorem asserts a maximum at balanced vectors and a minimum at concentrated vectors
\cite[Thm.\ 1.2]{Schmitt2025}. The maximality proof in \cite[\S2.1]{Schmitt2025} is presented as
model-generated and invokes Khovanskii--Teissier log-concavity for nef classes on a projective
orbifold, together with the remark that one may pass from the stack to a smooth projective variety by
a finite level-structure cover \cite[Rem.\ 2.1]{Schmitt2025}.

In \cite[\S3]{Schmitt2025}, Schmitt instead reduces to a finite flat cover by a complete scheme and
applies Lazarsfeld's inequality there using the projection formula \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Our Section~\ref{sec:stack-bridge} provides a third standard bridge: pass to the coarse moduli space,
use operational Chow, then compute intersections on a resolution. No new mathematics is involved; the
goal is simply to make every reduction step explicit.

\subsection{Positivity vs.\ nonnegativity in the unimodality step}

Schmitt's optimization theorem formalized in Lean assumes strict positivity (P)
\cite[Thm.\ 3.1]{Schmitt2025} to justify ratio arguments in slice sequences. For descendant integrals,
positivity is known (e.g.\ from Witten--Kontsevich recursions, as Schmitt notes) \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Nevertheless, Lemmas~\ref{lem:support}--\ref{lem:center} show that the ``move toward the center does
not decrease'' conclusion only needs nonnegativity plus log-concavity and palindromicity.

\section{Introduction}

Let $g,n\in \Z_{\ge 0}$ satisfy the stability condition $2g-2+n>0$, and set
\[
d:=\dim \Mgn = 3g-3+n.
\]
For $n\ge 1$, define the finite set of exponent vectors
\[
E(g,n) := \left\{\mathbf e=(e_1,\dots,e_n)\in \Z_{\ge 0}^n:\; \sum_{i=1}^n e_i = d\right\},
\]
and for $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ define the pure $\psi$--integral
\[
D(\mathbf e):=\int_{\Mgn}\psic_1^{e_1}\cdots \psic_n^{e_n}\in \Q_{\ge 0}.
\]

\begin{remark}[Empty-domain convention]
If one allows $n=0$ (as in some problem statements), then $E(g,0)$ is empty whenever $d>0$.
Under stability, $n=0$ forces $g\ge 2$ and hence $d=3g-3>0$, so $E(g,0)=\varnothing$ and the phrase
``$D$ achieves a maximum on $E(g,0)$'' is ill-posed in the usual logical sense.
Schmitt \cite{Schmitt2025} works throughout with $n>0$, and we do the same.
\end{remark}

\begin{definition}[Balanced vectors]
A vector $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ is \emph{balanced} if $|e_i-e_j|\le 1$ for all $i,j$.
Equivalently, writing $d=an+b$ with $0\le b<n$, the balanced vectors are the permutations of
\[
(\underbrace{a,\dots,a}_{n-b},\underbrace{a+1,\dots,a+1}_{b}).
\]
\end{definition}

Schmitt proves that $D$ is minimized on \emph{concentrated} vectors and maximized on balanced vectors
\cite[Thm.\ 1.2]{Schmitt2025}. Our focus here is the maximization statement.

\begin{theorem}[Balanced vectors maximize $D$]\label{thm:main}
Assume $n\ge 1$ and $2g-2+n>0$. Then the function $D:E(g,n)\to \Q$ attains its maximum at a balanced
vector.
\end{theorem}

\begin{remark}[Relation with \cite{Schmitt2025}]
Schmitt's proof of maximality (his \S2.1) is short and conceptual, relying on nefness of the
$\psic_i$ and Khovanskii--Teissier log-concavity \cite[\S2.1]{Schmitt2025}.
Section~\ref{sec:comparison} below records the precise points where our write-up differs:
we spell out one possible stack-to-variety reduction, and we isolate a discrete lemma that avoids
assuming strict positivity of the slice sequence (though Schmitt also provides positivity via
recursions in \cite[\S3]{Schmitt2025}).
\end{remark}

\section{A discrete reduction via balancing moves}\label{sec:balancing}

Throughout this section, fix integers $n\ge 1$ and $d\ge 0$ and write
\[
E(n,d):=\{\mathbf e\in \Z_{\ge 0}^n:\; \sum_i e_i=d\}.
\]
For $1\le i\le n$, let $\delta_i\in \Z^n$ be the $i$-th standard basis vector.

\begin{definition}[Balancing move]
If $\mathbf e\in E(n,d)$ and $e_i\ge e_j+2$, the \emph{balancing move} (or \emph{Robin Hood transfer})
from $i$ to $j$ is
\[
\mathbf e\longmapsto \mathbf e - \delta_i + \delta_j.
\]
\end{definition}

\begin{lemma}[Termination of balancing moves]\label{lem:terminate}
Starting from any $\mathbf e\in E(n,d)$, iterating balancing moves terminates after finitely many
steps at a balanced vector.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Let $\bar e:=d/n$ and consider the integer-valued potential
\[
\Phi(\mathbf e):=\sum_{k=1}^n (e_k-\bar e)^2.
\]
If $e_i\ge e_j+2$ and $\mathbf e'=\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j$, then a direct computation shows
\[
\Phi(\mathbf e')-\Phi(\mathbf e)=2(e_j-e_i)+2\le -2.
\]
Thus $\Phi$ strictly decreases along balancing moves and is bounded below by $0$, so the process
terminates. Termination means no pair satisfies $e_i\ge e_j+2$, i.e.\ the terminal vector is balanced.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}[Reduction to a pairwise transfer inequality]\label{prop:reduce}
Let $F:E(n,d)\to \R$ be any function such that for all $\mathbf e\in E(n,d)$ and all $i\neq j$ with
$e_i\ge e_j+2$ one has
\[
F(\mathbf e)\le F(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j).
\tag{TI}\label{eq:TI}
\]
Then $F$ attains its maximum on $E(n,d)$ at a balanced vector.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Let $\mathbf e_{\max}$ be a maximizer. By Lemma~\ref{lem:terminate}, applying balancing moves to
$\mathbf e_{\max}$ produces a balanced vector $\mathbf b$. Along each move, $F$ weakly increases by
\eqref{eq:TI}, hence $F(\mathbf b)\ge F(\mathbf e_{\max})$, so $\mathbf b$ is a balanced maximizer.
\end{proof}

Thus, to prove Theorem~\ref{thm:main} for $D$ it suffices to establish \eqref{eq:TI} for $F=D$.

\section{Geometric input and reduction to a smooth projective variety}\label{sec:stack-bridge}

This section packages the foundational input needed to apply Khovanskii--Teissier inequalities.
None of the statements are new; they are recorded here to make the reduction explicit.

\subsection{Nefness of $\psic_i$}

Let $L_i$ be the cotangent line bundle at the $i$-th marking on $\Mgn$, so that
$\psic_i=c_1(L_i)$.

\begin{fact}[Nefness of $\psic_i$]
Each $\psic_i$ is nef on $\Mgn$.
\end{fact}

\begin{remark}
Schmitt cites nefness in \cite[\S2.1, Step 2]{Schmitt2025} and in \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}
(with a pointer to \cite[Ch.\ XIV, Cor.\ 5.14]{ACG11}).
E-Jay: Insert your preferred primary reference for nefness of $\psic_i$ on $\overline{M}_{g,n}$ or
on the stack (e.g.\ Gibney--Keel--Morrison, or Arbarello--Cornalba--Griffiths).
\end{remark}

\subsection{Operational Chow and a resolution}

Let $p:\Mgn\to \overline{M}_{g,n}$ denote the coarse moduli morphism.

\begin{theorem}[Operational Chow comparison (Edidin/Kresch/Vistoli)]\label{thm:edidin}
With $\Q$-coefficients, pullback induces an isomorphism
\[
p^*:A_{\mathrm{op}}^*(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}\xrightarrow{\;\sim\;}A^*(\Mgn)_{\Q}.
\]
\end{theorem}

\begin{remark}
E-Jay: insert a precise citation (often quoted as ``Edidin, Thm.\ 4.40'') and verify the hypotheses
(separated DM stack, finite stabilizers, etc.) in the reference.
\end{remark}

In particular, each $\psic_i\in A^1(\Mgn)_{\Q}$ corresponds to a unique operational class
$\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^1(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$ with
$p^*\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}=\psic_i$.

\begin{lemma}[Tensor-power descent]\label{lem:descent}
For each $i$ there exists $m_i>0$ and a line bundle $M_i$ on $\overline{M}_{g,n}$ such that
$p^*M_i\simeq L_i^{\otimes m_i}$.
Consequently $\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}=\frac{1}{m_i}c_1(M_i)$ is a $\Q$-Cartier divisor class on the
coarse space.
\end{lemma}

\begin{remark}
E-Jay: provide a stacks-project/Vistoli reference that the cokernel of
$\mathrm{Pic}(\overline{M}_{g,n})\to \mathrm{Pic}(\Mgn)$ is torsion (equivalently, line bundles descend
after some tensor power).
\end{remark}

\begin{lemma}[Nefness descends to the coarse space]\label{lem:nef-descends}
If $L_i$ is nef on $\Mgn$, then $M_i$ is nef on $\overline{M}_{g,n}$, hence
$\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}$ is nef as a $\Q$-Cartier divisor class.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}[Proof sketch]
Let $C\subset \overline{M}_{g,n}$ be an irreducible curve and $\widetilde C\to C$ its normalization.
Consider the base change $\Mgn\times_{\overline{M}_{g,n}}\widetilde C$ and choose an irreducible
component $\widetilde{\mathcal C}$ dominating $\widetilde C$; then
$\widetilde{\mathcal C}\to \widetilde C$ is finite surjective.
Pulling back $p^*M_i\simeq L_i^{\otimes m_i}$ to $\widetilde{\mathcal C}$ gives
\[
\deg(M_i|_{\widetilde C})\cdot \deg(\widetilde{\mathcal C}\to \widetilde C)
=
\deg(L_i^{\otimes m_i}|_{\widetilde{\mathcal C}})\ge 0,
\]
since $L_i$ is nef on the stack.
Thus $\deg(M_i|_{\widetilde C})\ge 0$ for all curves, i.e.\ $M_i$ is nef.
\end{proof}

Now choose a resolution of singularities $\pi:\widetilde X\to \overline{M}_{g,n}$ with $\widetilde X$
smooth projective of dimension $d$. Set $\widetilde\psic_i:=\pi^*\psic_i^{\mathrm{coarse}}$; this is
nef on $\widetilde X$.

\begin{lemma}[Computing top intersections on a resolution]\label{lem:resolution}
Let $\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_d\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^1(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$ be $\Q$-Cartier divisor
classes. Then
\[
\degop\bigl((\alpha_1\cdots\alpha_d)\cap[\overline{M}_{g,n}]\bigr)
=
\degop\bigl((\pi^*\alpha_1\cdots\pi^*\alpha_d)\cap[\widetilde X]\bigr).
\]
In particular, for $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$,
\[
D(\mathbf e)
=
\int_{\widetilde X}\widetilde\psic_1^{e_1}\cdots \widetilde\psic_n^{e_n}.
\tag{$\ast$}\label{eq:Dtilde}
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Write $\alpha:=\alpha_1\cdots\alpha_d\in A_{\mathrm{op}}^d(\overline{M}_{g,n})_{\Q}$.
By definition of cap product and the projection formula in operational Chow,
\[
\alpha\cap[\overline{M}_{g,n}]
=
\alpha\cap \pi_*[\widetilde X]
=
\pi_*(\pi^*\alpha\cap[\widetilde X]).
\]
Taking degrees gives the claim.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}
Schmitt instead reduces to schemes by choosing a finite flat cover of $\Mgn$ by a complete scheme and
applying Khovanskii--Teissier there \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Both routes are standard; \eqref{eq:Dtilde} is convenient for directly invoking the classical
smooth-projective form of Alexandrov--Fenchel.
\end{remark}

\section{Log-concavity of two-point slices via Alexandrov--Fenchel}\label{sec:logconcave}

Fix $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ and distinct indices $i\neq j$. Let $q:=e_i+e_j$ and let
\[
C := \prod_{k\neq i,j}\widetilde\psic_k^{e_k}.
\]
For $t=0,1,\dots,q$ define the slice values
\[
S_t := \int_{\widetilde X}\widetilde\psic_i^{t}\,\widetilde\psic_j^{q-t}\,C.
\]
Thus $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$ (by \eqref{eq:Dtilde}).

\begin{lemma}[Palindromicity]\label{lem:pal}
$S_t=S_{q-t}$ for all $t$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
This is induced by the automorphism of $\Mgn$ swapping the $i$-th and $j$-th markings, which exchanges
$\psic_i$ and $\psic_j$ while fixing all other $\psic_k$. (Formally, one checks this on the stack and
then uses \eqref{eq:Dtilde}.)
\end{proof}

\subsection{Alexandrov--Fenchel / Khovanskii--Teissier}

We use the following standard inequality for nef divisor classes; see \cite[\S1.6]{Laz04}.

\begin{theorem}[Khovanskii--Teissier (2-by-2 form)]\label{thm:AF}
Let $Y$ be a smooth projective variety of dimension $d$ and let $D_1,\dots,D_d$ be nef
$\R$-Cartier divisor classes on $Y$. Then
\[
(D_1\cdots D_d)^2 \;\ge\; (D_1^2D_3\cdots D_d)\,(D_2^2D_3\cdots D_d).
\tag{AF}\label{eq:AF}
\]
\end{theorem}

\begin{lemma}[Slice log-concavity]\label{lem:lc}
For $1\le t\le q-1$ one has
\[
S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}.
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Apply Theorem~\ref{thm:AF} on $Y=\widetilde X$ with the following list of nef divisors:
\[
D_1=\widetilde\psic_i,\qquad D_2=\widetilde\psic_j,
\]
and $D_3,\dots,D_d$ consisting of
\begin{itemize}[leftmargin=2em]
\item $t-1$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_i$,
\item $q-t-1$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_j$,
\item and for each $k\neq i,j$, $e_k$ copies of $\widetilde\psic_k$.
\end{itemize}
The divisor count is $2+(t-1)+(q-t-1)+\sum_{k\neq i,j}e_k = q+\sum_{k\neq i,j}e_k = d$.
With this choice,
\[
(D_1\cdots D_d)=S_t,\quad (D_1^2D_3\cdots D_d)=S_{t+1},\quad (D_2^2D_3\cdots D_d)=S_{t-1},
\]
so \eqref{eq:AF} becomes $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$.
\end{proof}

\section{A discrete unimodality lemma without strict positivity}\label{sec:unimod}

Let $(S_t)_{t=0}^q$ be a nonnegative real sequence.

\begin{lemma}[Contiguous support]\label{lem:support}
If $S_t\ge 0$ and $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$ for all $1\le t\le q-1$, then
$\{t:\; S_t>0\}$ is an interval (possibly empty).
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
If $S_m=0$ and $S_{m-1}>0$, then $0=S_m^2\ge S_{m-1}S_{m+1}$ forces $S_{m+1}=0$.
Iterating forward and backward shows there are no internal zeros.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Palindromic log-concave sequences peak at the center]\label{lem:center}
Assume $(S_t)$ is nonnegative, log-concave (as above), and palindromic $S_t=S_{q-t}$.
Let $m=\lfloor q/2\rfloor$. Then for every integer $t\ge m+1$ one has
\[
S_{t-1}\ge S_t.
\]
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
By Lemma~\ref{lem:support}, positivity holds on a contiguous interval, and the inequality is trivial
outside that interval. We therefore assume $S_t>0$ on the relevant range.

Define ratios $R_t:=S_{t}/S_{t-1}$ (for $1\le t\le q$). Log-concavity implies $R_{t+1}\le R_t$:
indeed $S_t^2\ge S_{t-1}S_{t+1}$ is equivalent to $S_t/S_{t-1}\ge S_{t+1}/S_t$.

If $q=2m$ is even, palindromicity gives $S_{m-1}=S_{m+1}$, hence log-concavity at $m$ implies
\[
S_m^2\ge S_{m-1}S_{m+1}=S_{m+1}^2,
\]
so $S_m\ge S_{m+1}$, i.e.\ $R_{m+1}\le 1$. Since $(R_t)$ is weakly decreasing, for all $t\ge m+1$ we
have $R_t\le R_{m+1}\le 1$, i.e.\ $S_t\le S_{t-1}$.

If $q=2m+1$ is odd, palindromicity gives $S_m=S_{m+1}$, so $R_{m+1}=1$. Again monotonicity gives
$R_t\le 1$ for all $t\ge m+1$, hence $S_t\le S_{t-1}$.
\end{proof}

\section{Proof of the transfer inequality and Theorem~\ref{thm:main}}\label{sec:proof}

We now return to the descendant function $D$.

\begin{proposition}[Transfer inequality for $D$]\label{prop:TI-for-D}
Let $\mathbf e\in E(g,n)$ and suppose $e_i\ge e_j+2$. Then
\[
D(\mathbf e)\le D(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j).
\]
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Fix $\mathbf e$ and $i\neq j$ and form the slice sequence $S_t$ as in
Section~\ref{sec:logconcave}, with $q=e_i+e_j$ and $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$.
Lemma~\ref{lem:lc} gives log-concavity, and Lemma~\ref{lem:pal} gives palindromicity.
Since $e_i\ge e_j+2$, we have $e_i>\frac{q}{2}$, i.e.\ $e_i\ge \lfloor q/2\rfloor+1$.
Applying Lemma~\ref{lem:center} yields
\[
S_{e_i-1}\ge S_{e_i}.
\]
But $S_{e_i-1}=D(\mathbf e-\delta_i+\delta_j)$ and $S_{e_i}=D(\mathbf e)$, giving the claim.
\end{proof}

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{thm:main}]
By Proposition~\ref{prop:TI-for-D}, the descendant function $D$ satisfies the transfer inequality
\eqref{eq:TI}. Theorem~\ref{thm:main} now follows from Proposition~\ref{prop:reduce}.
\end{proof}

\section{Comments on \cite{Schmitt2025}}\label{sec:comparison}

This section is optional and can be shortened substantially.

\subsection{Comparison of reductions to the Khovanskii--Teissier setting}

Schmitt's main theorem asserts a maximum at balanced vectors and a minimum at concentrated vectors
\cite[Thm.\ 1.2]{Schmitt2025}. The maximality proof in \cite[\S2.1]{Schmitt2025} is presented as
model-generated and invokes Khovanskii--Teissier log-concavity for nef classes on a projective
orbifold, together with the remark that one may pass from the stack to a smooth projective variety by
a finite level-structure cover \cite[Rem.\ 2.1]{Schmitt2025}.

In \cite[\S3]{Schmitt2025}, Schmitt instead reduces to a finite flat cover by a complete scheme and
applies Lazarsfeld's inequality there using the projection formula \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Our Section~\ref{sec:stack-bridge} provides a third standard bridge: pass to the coarse moduli space,
use operational Chow, then compute intersections on a resolution. No new mathematics is involved; the
goal is simply to make every reduction step explicit.

\subsection{Positivity vs.\ nonnegativity in the unimodality step}

Schmitt's optimization theorem formalized in Lean assumes strict positivity (P)
\cite[Thm.\ 3.1]{Schmitt2025} to justify ratio arguments in slice sequences. For descendant integrals,
positivity is known (e.g.\ from Witten--Kontsevich recursions, as Schmitt notes) \cite[Prop.\ 3.2]{Schmitt2025}.
Nevertheless, Lemmas~\ref{lem:support}--\ref{lem:center} show that the ``move toward the center does
not decrease'' conclusion only needs nonnegativity plus log-concavity and palindromicity.
